articles.headline: Giving Nepotism a Good Name
articles.snippet: While corporate America’s family sagas are often mired in public drama, Comcast’s smooth father-to-son handoff offers a different model.
articles.abstract: While corporate America’s family sagas are often mired in public drama, Comcast’s smooth father-to-son handoff offers a different model.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The fundamental fact is that people love television,” said Ralph J. Roberts a few weeks ago. “And if you can provide them with more television, they love it even more.”

articles.headline: Faith Intertwines With Political Life for Clinton
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has increasingly been alluding to her spiritual life, but she has come under attack for it.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has increasingly been alluding to her spiritual life, but she has come under attack for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before her beliefs would be tested in the most wrenching of ways as first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton taught an adult Sunday school class on the importance of forgiveness. It is a lesson, she says, that she has harked back to often.

articles.headline: In Small Packages, Fewer Calories and More Profit

articles.abstract: In three years, sales of 100-calorie snack packs have passed the $20-million-a-year mark, as consumers don’t seem to mind paying more for less.

articles.headline: China Steps Up Its Safety Efforts
articles.snippet: China sentenced a former top drug safety official to death and disclosed an investigation into cellphone batteries after one reportedly exploded, killing a man.
articles.abstract: China sentenced a former top drug safety official to death and disclosed an investigation into cellphone batteries after one reportedly exploded, killing a man.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, July 6 — China made new public displays on Friday of its efforts to crack down on defective products, sentencing a former top drug safety official to death and disclosing an investigation into cellphone batteries after one reportedly exploded, killing a man when it pierced his heart.

articles.headline: 2 Doctors Held in British Bomb Plots Had Looked to U.S.
articles.snippet: Two of the medical doctors arrested in connection with  the bungled car bomb attacks had made inquiries about practicing medicine in the United States.
articles.abstract: Two of the medical doctors arrested in connection with  the bungled car bomb attacks had made inquiries about practicing medicine in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 6 — Two of the medical doctors arrested in connection with the bungled London and Glasgow car bomb attacks had made preliminary inquiries about practicing medicine in the United States, an American law enforcement official said Friday.
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Heart Therapy Strains Efforts to Limit Costs
articles.snippet: The nation’s most common cardiac malfunction, once thought harmless, is now being treated with costly medical procedures.
articles.abstract: The nation’s most common cardiac malfunction, once thought harmless, is now being treated with costly medical procedures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s most common cardiac malfunction, once thought harmless but now seen as a potential killer, is testing the ability of regulators to keep up with medical treatments being carried out with scant evidence of long-term effectiveness.

articles.headline: China Sentences Official to Death for Corruption
articles.snippet: A former high-ranking official at China’s top food and drug watchdog agency has been sentenced to death.
articles.abstract: A former high-ranking official at China’s top food and drug watchdog agency has been sentenced to death.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, July 6 — For the second time in three months, a former high-ranking official at China’s top food and drug watchdog agency has been sentenced to death for corruption and approving counterfeit drugs, the state-run news media said on Friday.

articles.headline: Wealthy Stake $25 Million in a War With the Sea
articles.snippet: It remains to be seen whether even endless expenditures can hold back the steady erosion of Nantucket Island.
articles.abstract: It remains to be seen whether even endless expenditures can hold back the steady erosion of Nantucket Island.
articles.lead_paragraph: NANTUCKET, Mass. — On this island, the phrase “money is no object” is more than a figure of speech. Starter homes sell for $800,000 or more, a coffee shop breakfast for two can top $50, and carpenters routinely commute to work by airplane.

articles.headline: Youth Groups Created by Kremlin Serve Putin’s Cause

articles.abstract: A youth movement seeks the ideological cultivation, some say indoctrination, of the first generation to come of age in post-Soviet Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 2 — Yulia Kuliyeva, only 19 and already a commissar, sat at a desk and quizzed each young person who sat opposite her, testing for ideological fitness to participate in summer camp.

articles.headline: Do Business and Islam Mix? Ask Him

articles.lead_paragraph: HE is a moderate Muslim religious leader and a descendant of the Prophet Muhammad. He is also a twice-married jet-setter, and he owns hundreds of racehorses, valuable stud farms, an exclusive yacht club on Sardinia and a lavish estate near Paris.

articles.headline: Increasing Rate of Foreclosures Upsets Atlanta
articles.snippet: Despite a vibrant local economy, Atlanta’s surge in foreclosures offers a glimpse of what experts fear may be in store for other U.S. cities.
articles.abstract: Despite a vibrant local economy, Atlanta’s surge in foreclosures offers a glimpse of what experts fear may be in store for other U.S. cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Despite a vibrant local economy, Atlanta homeowners are falling behind on mortgage payments and losing their homes at one of the highest rates in the nation, offering a troubling glimpse of what experts fear may be in store for other parts of the country.

articles.headline: British Press Assails Curbs on Reporting
articles.snippet: Media organizations say Britain’s tight reporting restrictions hamper their ability to cover terrorism stories.
articles.abstract: Media organizations say Britain’s tight reporting restrictions hamper their ability to cover terrorism stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 7 — With his picture splashed across the front pages of British newspapers, Mohammed Asha, a doctor in the National Health Service, over the last few days became the human face of a suspected plot to bomb a London nightclub and an attack at Glasgow Airport.

articles.headline: Ethics Tenet Is on Trial in Minnesota
articles.snippet: Can a newspaper maintain editorial independence under the shadows cast by its publisher’s conduct?
articles.abstract: Can a newspaper maintain editorial independence under the shadows cast by its publisher’s conduct?
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past few weeks, both The Minneapolis Star Tribune and The St. Paul Pioneer Press have been doing a bang-up job of covering a dramatic civil trial that has taken aim at one of the Twin Cities’ leading businessmen. The trial, and the accompanying coverage, has been full of allegations of bad faith, stolen data and riveting hallway commentary.
